questions.text: Which of the following structures is related to the area marked as A in the given image below?
questions.solution:
The cadaveric image shown is of the left lung. The arch of aorta is related to the area marked as A in the given image. 

The left lung is divided into superior and inferior lobes by the oblique fissure. The pulmonary root connects the medial surface of the lung to the heart and trachea. It is formed by structures that enter or leave the hilum. The left root is present inferior to the arch of the aorta.

The vertical sequence of structures at the left hilum from above to below is:

  • Pulmonary artery
  • Principal (hyparterial) bronchus, and
  • Inferior pulmonary vein

The arrangement of the lung hilar structures from the anterior to posterior in the order is:

  • Pulmonary vein
  • Pulmonary artery
  • Primary bronchus
  • Bronchial artery

The cadaveric image given below shows the structures related to the hilum of the left lung.

The cadaveric image given below shows the structures related to the hilum of the right lung.

Related Pearl: Structures related to the mediastinal surface and hilum of the lungs

Right lung:

  • Anterior to the hilum - superior vena cava and right brachiocephalic vein.
  • Posterior to this groove-  azygous vein.
  • Behind the hilum and pulmonary ligament- oesophagus.
  • The cardiac impression - right auricle, right atrium and right ventricle
  • Posteroinferiorly - inferior vena cava

Left lung:

  • The cardiac impression - left ventricle and auricle and right ventricle
  • Large groove that arches over the hilum and descends behind -  Arch of aorta and descending aorta.
  • Arrow groove that ascends to the apex- left subclavian artery
  • Superior to the aortic groove-  thoracic duct and esophagus.
  • Anterior to subclavian groove - left brachiocephalic vein.

questions.text: On examination of a newborn, you notice that the baby is hypotonic, has a high forehead, large anterior fontanelle, markedly separated cranial sutures, and hepatomegaly. Imaging reveals renal cysts. Investigations reveal elevated levels of very-long-chain fatty acids,  abnormal intermediates of bile acid synthesis, and deficiency of plasmalogens. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of hypotonia, dysmorphic facial features, hepatomegaly, renal cysts and accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids, abnormal intermediates of bile acid synthesis, with a deficiency of plasmalogens are suggestive of Zellweger syndrome. It is also known as cerebrohepatorenal syndrome 

It is caused by mutations in the PEX family of genes. As a result of this, there is a defective transport of the proteins from the cytosol to the peroxisomes. It severely impairs the functions of peroxisomes resulting in defective beta-oxidation of very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA), defective alpha oxidation, and impaired synthesis of bile acids and plasmalogens.

The child presents with

  • Dysmorphic facial features like wide anterior fontanelles markedly separated cranial sutures, epicanthal folds, etc
  • Profound developmental delay
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Renal cysts
  • Chondrodysplasia punctata- calcific stippling of the patellae, hips, and other epiphysis is seen in the majority of the patients.

Biochemical findings will show :

  • accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids, phytanic acid
  • abnormalities of the synthesis of bile acids
  • marked reduction of plasmalogens

There is no appropriate treatment for Zellweger syndrome. It is very severe and infants rarely survive beyond six months of age.

Other options:

Option B- Refsum disease is a disorder of alpha fatty acid oxidation. It occurs due to a defect in the enzyme phytanoyl-CoA hydroxylase (PAHX). It typically occurs in individuals between 10-15 years and is characterized by retinitis pigmentosa, anosmia, peripheral neuropathy, ichthyosis, cardiac conduction defects. There are elevated CSF protein levels without an increase in cells.

It can be diagnosed by elevated levels of phytanic acid and decreased activity of PAHX in the fibroblasts. VLCFA levels are normal in this condition.

Infantile Refsums disease presents at one to six months of age with severe developmental delay but generally without the dysmorphic features.

Option C- Neonatal adrenoleukodystrophy is a disorder of beta-oxidation that results in the accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA) in all tissues. The abnormalities primarily affect the central nervous system, adrenal cortex, and Leydig cells. The craniofacial appearance is dysmorphic, but less marked than Zellweger syndrome and consists primarily of mid-face hypoplasia. Patients typically have hepatomegaly but do not have renal microcysts or chondrodysplasia punctata.

Option D- Rhizomelic chondrodysplasia punctata is also a disorder of peroxisomes. They also present with profound mental retardation and dysmorphic facies. The unique feature is that it primarily affects the proximal long bones resulting in severe short stature. They might also have congenital cataracts and ichthyosis. VLCFA levels are not elevated in this condition.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old male patient presents to the casualty following a road traffic accident. On examination, he has a contaminated wound in his right forearm. He has received the full course of tetanus immunization and the last booster dose was at 15 years of age. Which of the following is advisable for this patient?

TT- Tetanus Toxoid

choices.text: Wound care + TT single dose + Human tetanus immunoglobulin

questions.solution:
A male patient with a contaminated wound with a full course of tetanus immunization taken 7 years back will come under category B of post-exposure prophylaxis for tetanus. Hence, he must be given proper wound care and one dose of tetanus toxoid.

Related Pearl: Post exposure prophylaxis for tetanus

Prophylaxis is given based on patient category:

A. Full immunization or a booster dose within the past 5 years.

B. Full immunization or a booster dose > 5 years ago but < 10 years.

C. Full immunization or a booster dose > 10 years ago.

D. Unknown or never taken immunization

Category Clean wound Unclean wound
A Only wound care Only wound care
B Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose
C Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose + Human tetanus immunoglobulin 
D Wound care + TT complete course Wound care + TT complete course + Human tetanus immunoglobulin

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with facial redness as shown in the image. He also complains of burning and tingling sensation on the skin which increases on sunlight exposure and wind. The redness of the lesion increases when he consumes hot and spicy beverages and alcohol.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows erythema and papules on the central face, which along with a history of triggering factors like sunlight, wind, spicy food, and alcohol points towards a diagnosis of acne rosacea.

Acne rosacea is a disorder that appears mainly in people within 30 to 50 years of age. The lesions are mainly present on the convexities of the face. There are mainly 4 subtypes:

  • Erythematotelangiectatic rosacea (ETTR): Patients complain of a gradual increase in facial redness. They mainly appear on the lateral cheeks, the ears, and sometimes the sides of the neck. This redness can be triggered by various factors like sunlight, wind, hot, spicy food, and alcohol.
  • Papulopustular rosacea (PPR): Patients complain of red bumps or pimples that are located principally on the proximal cheeks, central chin, nose, and central forehead
  • Phymatous rosacea (PR): Occurs in a patient with preexisting PPR. They complain of thickening of the distal nose with a prominence of pores.
  • Ocular rosacea (OR): Patients complain of dryness and gritty sensation in the eye.

Other options:

Option B- Acne vulgaris is commonly seen in adolescents. It is commonly seen in the face, but can also be present on the back and chest. The lesions may present as comedonal acne, papulopustular acne, nodular acne, etc.

 

Option C- Melasma is seen mainly in women. It manifests as hyperpigmented macules which are mainly seen in the upper lip, the malar regions, the forehead, and the chin and may be associated with the darkening of the nipples. The affected skin is brown in color. They are bilateral and symmetrical.

Option D- Systemic lupus erythematosus presents as cutaneous erythema on light‐exposed areas. It is a butterfly-shaped rash on the cheeks. The nasolabial folds are spared.

questions.text: A young woman presented with a history of discharge from the left ear for the past 4 weeks, deep-seated ear pain for the past 1 week, and diplopia for the past 2 days. Her symptoms have progressed gradually over the past 4 weeks. Which of the following signs/syndrome is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is a typical presentation of Gradenigo syndrome. 

Patients with petrositis may present with Gradenigo syndrome. Gradenigo syndrome is a triad with the following symptoms:

  • Diplopia or double vision due to cranial nerve VI  palsy
  • Facial pain or deep-seated ear pain due to cranial nerve V involvement
  • Persistent ear discharge due to otitis media

The patient may also have a fever, headache, vomiting, and neck rigidity. The involvement of facial and statoacoustic nerves results in facial paralysis and recurrent vertigo respectively.

Diagnosis of petrositis is done by a CT scan and MRI. CT scan of the temporal bone shows bony details of the air cells and petrous apex. MRI helps to detect the presence of fluid or pus.

Treatment with suitable intravenous antibacterial therapy should precede and follow surgical intervention. Definitive management would include mastoidectomy. 

Other options:

Option A: Griesinger sign is edema over the mastoid, which is secondary to the thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein. It is seen in sigmoid sinus thrombosis.

Option C: Grisel syndrome refers to non-traumatic atlantoaxial joint dislocation. Patient presents with neck pain and torticollis.

Option D: Holman-Miller sign or antral sign is the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus. It is a pathognomonic feature of angiofibroma.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the emergency room with profound drowsiness. On examination, he is found to have respiratory depression, with a respiratory rate of 5 cycles/minute. His symptoms are traced back to a drug derived from the plant shown below. Which of the following is the antidote to this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The suitable antidote to this patient presenting with features of opiate intoxication is naloxone. The derivative drug, opium is derived from the Papaver somniferum plant as shown in the clinical vignette.

Toxic parts of the plant include the unripe fruit capsule and the latex juice. Active principles of opium are grouped under phenanthrenes (morphine, codeine, heroin) and benzyl-isoquinolones (papaverine, narcotin).

These drugs act on mu, kappa, delta receptors in the CNS and mediate the effects of euphoria, analgesia, respiratory depression, gastrointestinal dysmotility, and miosis. 

The antidote to opiate intoxication is a competitive opiate antagonist named naloxone which competes with opioids at their receptor sites. Dose: 0.4-2 mg IV (It may be repeated every 10-15 minutes up to a maximum dose of 10 mg).

Other options:

Option A - Flumazenil is the antidote to treat benzodiazepine (BZD) intoxication. Benzodiazepines (alprazolam, flunitrazepam) are sedative-hypnotics and symptoms of intoxication include normal vital signs, sedation, diplopia, ataxia, slurred speech, and impaired motor function. Flumazenil acts as a competitive antagonist at the site of BZD action, which is the gamma-aminobutyric acid receptor. 

Option C - Physostigmine is used in the treatment of anticholinergic toxicity due to atropine. Atropine is the anticholinergic active principle derived from tropane alkaloids such as Datura stramonium and Atropa belladonna. Toxidrome consists of features such as tachycardia, hyperthermia, agitation, delirium, mydriasis, dry flushed skin, and urinary retention. Physostigmine is a reversible acetylcholine esterase inhibitor that increases acetylcholine concentrations in the synaptic cleft to mitigate the effects of atropine toxicity. 

Option D - Atropine is used in the treatment of cholinergic toxicity due to organophosphates (DDT, parathion, malathion). Symptoms of cholinergic toxicity include bradycardia, respiratory depression, and autonomic symptoms of salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation. Atropine used in association with pralidoxime act as competitive inhibitors at the nicotinic and muscarinic acetylcholine receptors to neutralize the toxicity.

questions.text: A mother brings her 4-month-old female child to the outpatient department. She was delivered by C-section. The pregnancy was complicated by oligohydramnios and breech presentation. On examination of the child, you notice the finding shown in the image below. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
A Pavlik harness after closed reduction is the most appropriate management for this infant, with history and examination suggestive of developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). The image shows one knee (affected knee) at a lower level compared to the other, which is known as Galeazzi's sign.

Developmental dysplasia of the hip or congenital dysplasia of the hip is characterized by spontaneous dislocation of the hip joint before, during, or shortly after birth. Risk factors for DDH include-

  • Sex of the baby - Female gender is more susceptible 
  • Intrauterine positioning - Breech position 
  • Oligohydramnios
  • Genetic predisposition 

Examination of the developmental dysplasia of the hip-

  • Tests to check instability of the hip -
    • Ortolani test: To perform this test, the infant is supine, with the hip and knee flexed. With the thumb placed over the medial thigh and the index finger on the greater trochanter, the hip is gently abducted. This reduces the femoral head into the acetabulum producing a palpable "clunk". 
    • Barlow test: This test is done within 2–3 days of birth. To perform this test, the infant is supine with the knees fully flexed and the hip at 90° of flexion. Gentle adduction results in a posterior subluxation or dislocation of an easily dislocatable femoral head, producing a palpable "clunk"
  • Galeazzi's test is shown in the above image. It is done between 3 to 8-month aged children in unilateral cases of developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). To perform this test, the child is in the supine position with the hip and knee in flexion. The level of both the knee joints is noted with respect to a horizontal line. Normally both knees should be at the same level. In DDH, the affected knee is seen at a lower level indicating femoral shortening. This is also known as the Allis sign. 
  • Marked asymmetry of the inguinal, gluteal, thigh, or popliteal folds.
  • Decreased abduction on the affected side.
  • Positive tredelenburg sign
  • Limb-length discrepancy

Treatment of DDH includes early closed reduction with splinting or casts. If closed reduction cannot be achieved in long-standing dislocations, an open reduction may become necessary.

  • < 6 months: Closed reduction with Pavlik harness or Von Rosen splint is done.  
  • 6-18 months: Closed or open reduction with hip spica application is done.
  • 1.5 years- 3 years: Open reduction and pelvic or femoral osteotomies may be required
  • 3-8 years: Femoral shortening or pelvic osteotomies.
  • >8 years: Femoral and pelvic osteotomies or total hip replacement considered

questions.text: A neonate has a cardiac murmur and the eye finding shown in the image below. Investigations revealed bilateral hearing defect. The mother gives a history of viral exanthem during the first trimester of the pregnancy. The most common cardiac defect seen in such neonates is:
questions.solution:
Maternal history of viral exanthem in the first trimester and the image showing the presence of bilateral congenital cataract and hearing defect is suggestive of congenital rubella syndrome. Patent ductus arteriosus is the most common cardiac defect associated with this condition.

Congenital rubella syndrome is associated with rubella infection in mothers in early pregnancy. The classic triad of congenital rubella syndrome includes:

  • Sensorineural hearing loss
  • Congenital cataract
  • Congenital heart disease (most commonly: patent ductus arteriosus)

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: An individual consumed a balanced meal containing carbohydrates, proteins, and fats. Immediately after the meal, assuming that carbohydrates were mainly metabolized, what will the respiratory quotient be?
questions.solution:
The respiratory quotient (RQ) immediately after a balanced meal in which carbohydrates in the food were mainly metabolized will be 1.0.

The respiratory quotient refers to the ratio of carbon dioxide production to oxygen utilization. It estimates the relative utilization of different foods by the body.

Carbohydrates- When carbohydrates are metabolized, one molecule of carbon dioxide is released when one molecule of oxygen is utilized. Therefore, the RQ of carbohydrates is 1. This occurs immediately after a meal when the majority of carbohydrates are metabolized.

Fats- When fats are oxidized, with every 100 molecules of oxygen utilized, an average of 70 carbon dioxide molecules are released. The RQ of fat is therefore 0.70. This happens because when oxygen reacts with fats, a large amount of it combines with hydrogen from the fats, forming water instead of carbon dioxide. Around 8-10 hours after a meal the carbohydrate stores are depleted and fats are utilized. The RQ becomes 0.70. In severe untreated diabetes, carbohydrates are not utilized as they require insulin. Hence, the RQ remains near that of fat metabolism, i.e., 0.70.

Proteins- When proteins are oxidized, with every 100 molecules of oxygen utilized, an average of 80 carbon dioxide molecules are released. Therefore, the RQ of proteins is 0.8. Protein utilization is better estimated by measuring nitrogen excretion. The average protein contains about 16% nitrogen. During the metabolism of the protein, most of the nitrogen is excreted as urea, uric acid, creatinine, and other nitrogen products in the urine and around 10% is excreted in the feces. The utilization of proteins mainly occurs during starvation, when the carbohydrate and the fat stores have been depleted.

questions.text: Which of the following patients can be intubated using succinylcholine as a muscle relaxant?
questions.solution:
Succinylcholine can be administered in liver disease.

Succinylcholine is a depolarizing muscle relaxant. It has a rapid onset of action and an ultra-short duration of action. It stimulates cholinergic receptors at the neuromuscular junction and muscarinic autonomic sites. The ultrashort duration of action is because it gets rapidly hydrolyzed by butyrylcholinesterase. A decreased concentration of butyrylcholinesterase will prolong the blockade produced by succinylcholine.

In liver disease, the amount of butyrylcholinesterase will decrease (20% of normal), leading to prolonged neuromuscular blockade, but it is not a major concern in clinical practice.

Succinylcholine chloride is used to facilitate tracheal intubation. It provides skeletal muscle relaxation during surgery or mechanical ventilation.

Succinylcholine is contraindicated in: 

  • Burns patients
  • Muscle dystrophies (like Duchenne muscular dystrophy)
  • Known hypersensitivity
  • Multiple trauma, head injury

Related Pearl: Conditions causing susceptibility to succinylcholine-induced hyperkalemia

The conditions that predispose to hyperkalemia following succinylcholine administration are:

  • Burn injury
  • Massive trauma, head and spinal cord injury
  • Severe intra-abdominal infection
  • Encephalitis, tetanus and stroke
  • Neuropathy like Guillain-Barre syndrome
  • Severe Parkinson’s disease
  • Prolonged total body immobilization
  • Hemorrhagic shock with metabolic acidosis
  • Myopathies (eg, Duchenne’s dystrophy)

So, the use of succinylcholine is relatively contraindicated in patients having these conditions.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old boy presented with yellowish discoloration of the skin and sclerae for the last 3 days. He is otherwise asymptomatic. He had a viral fever one week ago which has now resolved. His investigations are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Serum bilirubin: 2.4 mg/dL
Unconjugated bilirubin: 2.1mg/dL
Conjugated bilirubin: 0.3mg/dL
Serum AST and ALT: Normal
questions.solution:
This patient has a short history of jaundice, which appeared only during a period of stress (viral fever). The lab reports show increased unconjugated bilirubin (normal 0.2-0.8 mg/dL) and normal AST and ALT levels. All this points toward a diagnosis of Gilbert syndrome.

Gilbert syndrome is a benign, familial disorder characterized by mild intermittent jaundice usually seen during stress, fatigue, or alcohol use. The condition is recognized to arise from a mutation in the promoter region of the UGT1A1 gene, which results in mildly decreased UDP-glucuronyltransferase production. This causes a reduction in the liver's ability to conjugate bilirubin, thus causing unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The total bilirubin value is usually < 3 mg/dL. 

Other options:

Option A: Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a benign disease that is characterized by chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and bilirubinuria. Patients are asymptomatic and other laboratory tests are normal. Liver biopsy shows characteristic deposition of black-colored pigment in the lysosomes of the centrilobular hepatocytes.

Option B: Rotor syndrome is similar to Dubin-Johnson syndrome but has a milder presentation. Conjugated bilirubin levels are elevated. The liver biopsy does not show pigment deposition.

Option D: Crigler-Najjar syndrome is another syndrome that has unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is of two types, with type 1 having absent/trace UDP-glucoronyltransferase production and type 2 having <10% of the normal enzyme activity. Type 1 is far more severe and leads to kernicterus and neurological damage in infancy.

questions.text: A 21-year-old male patient presents with low-grade fever, loss of weight,  dry nocturnal cough, dyspnea, and wheezing for the past 6 months  The eosinophil count is markedly increased along with a high level of serum IgE and filarial antibodies. Following treatment with diethylcarbamazine, he developed a severe allergic reaction. This is known as:
questions.solution:
Following treatment with diethylcarbamazine (DEC), the severe allergic reaction that may occur is known as the Mazzotti reaction. It occurs due to the death of microfilariae. The clinical scenario given above is suggestive of tropical pulmonary eosinophilia.

Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia is a manifestation of occult filariasis. It presents with low-grade fever, weight loss, and pulmonary symptoms like a dry nocturnal cough, dyspnea, and wheezing. There is an increase in the eosinophil count, IgE, and filarial antibodies. The condition is treated with DEC.

Diethylcarbamazine is the drug of choice for filariasis. It is given orally (the dose is 6 mg/ kg body weight daily for 12 days). It has both macro and microfilaricidal properties. The Mazzotti reaction that may develop can be controlled with antihistamines and steroids.

Other options:

Option B- A Jarisch–Herxheimer reaction is a transient clinical phenomenon that occurs in patients infected with spirochetes like syphilis, leptospirosis, Lyme disease, and relapsing fever, who are treated with antibiotics. The reaction occurs within 24 hours of antibiotic therapy. It generally manifests as fever, chills, rigors, nausea and vomiting, headache, tachycardia, hypotension, hyperventilation, flushing, myalgia, and exacerbation of skin lesions. It is an acute, self-limiting condition.

Option C- Hoigne Syndrome is a pseudoanaphylactic or pseudoallergic reaction that occurs after intramuscular administration of penicillin G procaine or benzathine. It is not due to a penicillin allergy. 

Option D- Meyer's-Kouwenaar syndrome is a synonym for occult filariasis. It occurs as a result of a hypersensitivity reaction to microfilariae antigens. Microfilariae are not found in the blood. It presents with massive eosinophilia, hepatosplenomegaly, and pulmonary symptoms.

questions.text:
Mr. Ramesh is a 55-year-old man who has pledged for cornea donation. History of which of the following diseases would render his cornea unfit for transplantation?
  1. Hypertension
  2. COVID-19 Infection
  3. Leprosy
  4. Diabetes mellitus
  5. Tetanus
questions.solution:
Diabetes and hypertension are not considered as a contraindication for carrying out cornea donation.

Contraindications for eye donation include Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, HIV, syphilis, leprosy, tetanus, and COVID-19.

In view of the recent pandemic, COVID -19 has also been included as a contraindication for eye donation as per the eye bank 2020 guidelines.

Contraindications for transplantation: These include conditions with a potential risk of transmission of local or systemic communicable disease from donor to recipient.

  • Death of unknown cause.
  • Death with progressive neurodegenerative diseases like
    • Chronic idiopathic demyelinating polyneuropathy
    • Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
    • Multiple sclerosis
    • Huntington’s chorea
    • Alzheimer’s disease
    • Myasthenia gravis
    • Parkinson’s syndrome
    • Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
  • Active meningitis, viral encephalitis
  • Active septicemia at the time of death
  • Active viral hepatitis
  • Congenital rubella
  • Reye’s syndrome
  • Suspected rabies and persons who, within the past six months, were bitten by an animal suspected to be infected with rabies
  • Active miliary tuberculosis
  • Hepatitis B surface antigen-positive donors, Hepatitis C seropositive donors
  • HTLV-I or HTLV-II infection
  • HIV seropositive donors
  • Active syphilis or seropositive for syphilis.
  • Leprosy
  • COVID-19 infection
  • Tetanus

questions.text: Which of the following drugs acts by causing irreversible inhibition of the initiation complex through binding of the 30S ribosomal subunit?
questions.solution:
Aminoglycosides like gentamicin act by causing irreversible inhibition of the initiation complex through binding of the 30S ribosomal subunit. They cause misreading and premature termination of mRNA translation. 

Aminoglycosides include streptomycin, gentamicin, tobramycin, amikacin, and kanamycin. They are bactericidal and the killing is concentration-dependent.

They are used in the treatment of aerobic gram-negative bacterial infections such as urinary tract infections, mycobacterial infections, tularemia, respiratory infections in cystic fibrosis, and other pseudomonal infections. Anaerobic bacteria are intrinsically resistant to aminoglycosides because the transport of aminoglycosides across the cytoplasmic membrane requires oxygen.  

The adverse effects of aminoglycosides include-

  • Ototoxicity is characterized by irreversible high-frequency hearing loss and vestibular dysfunction. Streptomycin and gentamicin are the most vestibulotoxic. Amikacin, kanamycin, and neomycin mainly affect auditory functions. 
  • Nephrotoxicity due to damage to proximal tubular cells. Neomycin is the most nephrotoxic. Streptomycin is the least nephrotoxic.
  • Acute neuromuscular blockade and apnea. Neuromuscular blockade may be reversed by intravenous administration of a Ca2+ salt. 

Other options

Options A and B- Chloramphenicol and clindamycin act by binding to the 50S subunit of the ribosome.

Option D- Vancomycin is a glycopeptide that inhibits cell wall synthesis. It binds to terminal dipeptide D-Ala-D-Ala of peptidoglycan to inhibit cell wall synthesis.

Related Pearl: Protein synthesis inhibitors: Primary subunit of ribosome binding

Mnemonic: 50 CELLS arranged into 30 TEAM

50s subunit binding:

  • C: Chloramphenicol, Clindamycin
  • E: Erythromycin (macrolides)
  • L: Lincosamides
  • L: Linezolid
  • S: Streptogramins

30s subunit binding

  • Te: Tetracyclines
  • Am: Aminoglycosides

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presented to the hospital with malaise, pain abdomen, and blood in the stools. On examination, the patient also has foot drop. Laboratory investigations reveal anemia, elevated ESR, and negative ANCA. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in the given clinical scenario is polyarteritis nodosa. The presence of foot drop is highly suggestive of mononeuritis multiplex. Mononeuritis multiplex in combination with malaise, pain abdomen, blood in the stools, anemia, elevated ESR, and negative ANCA is highly suggestive of polyarteritis nodosa.

Polyarteritis nodosa is necrotizing arteritis involving medium-sized vessels. It may present insidiously with fever, malaise, weight loss, arthralgia, myalgia, or neuropathy. Mononeuritis multiplex is most commonly seen as a foot drop. Patients also develop symptoms related to vasculitis of a particular organ system. Cutaneous manifestations are skin ulcers, digital gangrene, and livedo reticularis. Renal involvement is common and manifests as hypertension or renal failure. GI involvement presents as abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, bleeding, bowel infarction, and perforation.

There are no specific serologic tests. Laboratory investigations reveal anemia, leukocytosis, elevated ESR. Patients with classic polyarteritis nodosa are negative for ANCA. Diagnosis is confirmed only by confirming vasculitis on biopsy.

Other options:

Option B: Takayasu arteritis is an inflammatory and stenotic disease of medium- and large-sized arteries- usually aortic arch and its branches. It is suspected in a young woman with decreased or absent peripheral pulses, blood pressure discrepancies, and arterial bruits. There is elevated ESR, mild anemia, and elevated immunoglobulin levels. Diagnosis is confirmed with arteriography.

Option C: Cogan's syndrome is characterized by interstitial keratitis and vestibulo-auditory symptoms. Vasculitis of aorta and aortic valve may also be associated.

Option D: Wegener's granulomatosis is a granulomatous vasculitis of the upper and lower respiratory tracts with glomerulonephritis. Laboratory findings include a markedly elevated ESR, mild anemia, leukocytosis, hypergammaglobulinemia, elevated rheumatoid factor. ANCA is usually positive.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presented with complaints of blurred vision and urinary incontinence for the past 2 months. MRI showed scattered plaques in the patient’s brain and spinal cord. Over the next few months, some of these plaques diminished in size, while others appeared in new locations. These plaques would most likely show selective loss of which of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of multiple sclerosis, which is associated with selective loss of myelin.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune demyelinating disease characterized by episodes of neurological deficits occurring at different times, due to patchy white matter lesions that involve various sites of the brain.

The condition is caused by an autoimmune response directed against components of the myelin sheath.

In most cases, the initial manifestation includes unilateral visual impairment due to the involvement of the optic nerve (optic neuritis). Involvement of the brainstem causes cranial nerve signs such as ataxia, nystagmus, and internuclear ophthalmoplegia. Spinal cord lesions give rise to motor and sensory impairment of the trunk and limbs, spasticity, and loss of bladder control. The course of MS varies, with many relapses and remissions.

Other options:

Option A: Synaptophysin is a neuroendocrine marker seen in small cell carcinoma

Option B: α-synuclein is are the inclusions found in Parkinson disease and Multiple system atrophy

Option C: β-Amyloid is associated with senile cerebral amyloidosis and seen in Alzheimer's disease

questions.text: A 50-year-old man was arrested by the police for disrupting peace in a hotel. He refused to pay his hotel bills saying that he was the prime minister and all services are free for him. When the hotel staff confronted him, he got angry and damaged some hotel property. What are his symptoms suggestive of?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms are suggestive of a delusion of grandeur (megalomania).

Grandiose delusions, delusions of grandeur, or megalomania refer to the exaggerated conception of one's importance, power, or identity. The patient may believe that he is a famous celebrity or has supernatural powers.

A delusion is a false, firm, fixed (unshakable) belief that is not in keeping with the patient’s socio-cultural and educational background.

Delusions are of two types based on their origin:

  • Primary: Delusions that do not occur in response to another psychopathological form such as mood disorder.
  • Secondary: Delusions that are secondary to other morbid psychological conditions like depressive moods and hallucinations. They are understandable when a detailed psychiatric history and examination are available.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man, with no known medical illness, came for a routine medical check-up. His chest radiograph is presented to you. Identify the incorrect statement with respect to the X-ray shown below.

choices.text: The structure marked number 2 is the right ventricular border
The structure marked 1 is the trachea
The structure marked 3 is the left ventricular border
The structure marked 4 is the aortic arch

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement is option A because the structure marked as 2 is the right atrial border (not the right ventricular border). The given image is posteroanterior (PA) view of a normal chest x-ray. Structures marked in the X-Ray are as follows:

  1. Trachea
  2. Right atrial border
  3. Left ventricular border
  4. Aortic arch

Chest x-rays can be described as posteroanterior (PA) or anteroposterior (AP) views. This indicates the direction in which the x-ray beam traverses from the patient to the detector.

PA view means that the x-ray beam enters from the posterior aspect of the patient and exits anteriorly to reach the film.

AP view means that the x-ray beam enters the patient from the anterior aspect and exits from the posterior aspect, reaching the film.

A left lateral decubitus view is one taken with the patient’s left side down.

questions.text:
Based on the new update to the MELD score i.e. MELD 3.0, an elderly woman with end-stage liver disease now has a higher score and is deemed eligible for a liver transplant. Which of the following is a new component that has been added to the MELD 3.0 scoring system?

MELD- Model for end-stage liver disease
questions.solution:
The female gender is one of the new components that has been added to the MELD 3.0 scoring system.

The Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) is used as an indicator of short-term survival in patients with end-stage liver disease, and to determine organ allocation priorities for liver transplantation. According to the previous model, MELDNa, the components of the scoring system were:

  • Serum creatinine
  • Serum bilirubin
  • Serum sodium, and
  • INR (international normalized ratio)

The updated MELD 3.0 scoring system has added two additional components- serum albumin and female gender. 

The addition of these two components and certain adjustments made in the other components has led to a better scoring system. MELD 3.0 allows for a more accurate prediction of mortality than the previous MELDNa scoring system. An important improvement is that it addresses factors that can affect wait-list outcomes such as sex disparity. MELD 3.0 is able to correctly reclassify almost 9% of patients to a higher MELD tier, giving them a much better chance of transplantation, particularly in women. 

It is estimated that almost 20 waitlist deaths can be reduced per year with the new MELD 3.0 scoring system.

Related Pearl: Revised Model for End-stage liver disease (MELD) scoring system: MELD 3.0

MELD 3.0 score has the following components (Mnemonic F BASIC)

  • Female sex
  • Bilirubin
  • Albumin
  • Serum sodium (mEq/L)
  • INR (International Normalized ratio)
  • Creatinine

Uses:

  • Predict short-term prognosis in patients undergoing transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) insertion
  • Assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation
  • Assess prognosis in cirrhosis
